assessments.task_description:
There will be ten tutorials over the course of the semester. Tutorial participation requires genuine preparation, which includes completing the set readings and attending the lecture. Please note that active participation is required. Participation marks are not given simply for attendance (see the criteria below). If 5 or fewer tutorials are participated in, the student will receive 0 tutorial participations marks.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Topic: Students can choose any topic they wish to write on. They can feel free to consult with the tutor and lecturers. It would be helpful to consider writing on subjects covered in the course.

Referencing Style: Students are strongly encouraged to use Chicago style for references and bibliographies: http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/tools_citationguide/citation-guide-1.html

Cover Sheet: Students must use and complete the provided cover sheet for this essay found in Blackboard. An essay submitted without a completed cover sheet will be graded accordingly, based on the marking criteria. Falsified or misreprestented information on the cover sheet is a breach of the student code of conduct and will be referred to the academic integrity unit.

Word Limits: 2,000 words. Within ±10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes, however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Introduction

This lecture offers an introduction to the course, its assessment, and prompts students to think about the Bible as an historical and contemporary artefact of continuing relevance.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Introduction This lecture offers an introduction to the course, its assessment, and prompts students to think about the Bible as an historical and contemporary artefact of continuing relevance.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: How was the Bible Written I: From Scrolls to King James

This lecture introduces the complex history of how the Bible came to be written and compiled together as canon. It traces the Bible's origins from ancient Hebrew scriptures to Christian canons, including key translations, such as the Latin Vulgate and King James Version.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 2: How was the Bible Written I: From Scrolls to King James
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: How was the Bible Written I: From Scrolls to King James This lecture introduces the complex history of how the Bible came to be written and compiled together as canon. It traces the Bible's origins from ancient Hebrew scriptures to Christian canons, including key translations, such as the Latin Vulgate and King James Version.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: How was the Bible Written II: Making the Bible

This lecture looks at how different Christian canons emerged, and why various Christian traditions include different books in their bibles. It explores historical impacts of the Septuagint, the Protestant Reformation, and scholarly theories like the Documentary Hypothesis.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 3: How was the Bible Written II: Making the Bible
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: How was the Bible Written II: Making the Bible This lecture looks at how different Christian canons emerged, and why various Christian traditions include different books in their bibles. It explores historical impacts of the Septuagint, the Protestant Reformation, and scholarly theories like the Documentary Hypothesis.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: How was the Bible Written III: Canon from Conflict

This lecture examines how various conflicts, including between Jews and Romans, as well as Christian responses to heresies like Marcionism, Gnosticism, and Montanism, helped to shape the biblical canons we have today.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 4: How was the Bible Written III: Canon from Conflict
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: How was the Bible Written III: Canon from Conflict This lecture examines how various conflicts, including between Jews and Romans, as well as Christian responses to heresies like Marcionism, Gnosticism, and Montanism, helped to shape the biblical canons we have today.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Reading Genesis in Context

This lecture will outline the context in which the Book of Genesis was composed and explore it's reception history: the primeval history of divine creation in the first book of the Pentateuch, the ancestral history of Abraham's covenant with God, and the significance of Genesis for Western thought and culture.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Reading Genesis in Context This lecture will outline the context in which the Book of Genesis was composed and explore it's reception history: the primeval history of divine creation in the first book of the Pentateuch, the ancestral history of Abraham's covenant with God, and the significance of Genesis for Western thought and culture.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Reading Job in Context

This lecture will outline the context in which the Book of Job was composed and explore it's reception history: it will detail Job's major theme of theodicy - the problem of human suffering and divine justice in the world - and discuss its ongoing significance for Western thought and culture.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Reading Job in Context This lecture will outline the context in which the Book of Job was composed and explore it's reception history: it will detail Job's major theme of theodicy - the problem of human suffering and divine justice in the world - and discuss its ongoing significance for Western thought and culture.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Reading Matthew in Context

This lecture will outline the context in which the Gospel of Matthew was composed and explore it's reception history: it will detail Matthew's construction of Jesus in the specific context of his community of Jewish Christians, and discuss the Gospel's ongoing significance for Western thought and culture.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Reading Matthew in Context This lecture will outline the context in which the Gospel of Matthew was composed and explore it's reception history: it will detail Matthew's construction of Jesus in the specific context of his community of Jewish Christians, and discuss the Gospel's ongoing significance for Western thought and culture.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Empire and the Bible

This lecture shows how the Bible served as a vehicle for colonial expansionism and it reflects on the justifications for colonisation through Biblical interpretations.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Empire and the Bible This lecture shows how the Bible served as a vehicle for colonial expansionism and it reflects on the justifications for colonisation through Biblical interpretations.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: The Bible in Politics and Popular Culture

The Bible continues as a source to fuel imagination and story-telling, from Hollywood films to politicians who rely on ideas from the Bible to secure a moral population through returning to Biblical roots.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 9: The Bible in Politics and Popular Culture
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: The Bible in Politics and Popular Culture The Bible continues as a source to fuel imagination and story-telling, from Hollywood films to politicians who rely on ideas from the Bible to secure a moral population through returning to Biblical roots.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: No Lecture Public Holiday

This lecture examines the transmission and reception of the Bible in Australia, as both a source of colonial oppression and as an avenue to liberation for Indigenous peoples. The lecture will describe experiences of dispossession and emancipation, drawing on examples from within the Queensland community of Yarrabah.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Indigenous Australia and the Bible

This lecture explores alternative readings of the Bible from historically marginalised populations, focussing on Queer theology and Black liberation theology.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Indigenous Australia and the Bible This lecture explores alternative readings of the Bible from historically marginalised populations, focussing on Queer theology and Black liberation theology.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: The Bible and Liberation: Queer and Black Readings

The Bible has served as a window into the past as well as into the future. This lecture will explore how the Bible resources environmentalist movements, and at times, climate change denial.
